snippet: The pilot at the controls on Asiana Flight 214 was said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying a Boeing 777, and an airline spokeswoman said that it was his first time piloting a 777 into San Francisco.
abstract: Passengers and aviation officials describe crash of Asiana Flight 214 at San Francisco International Airport in harrowing detail; pilot Lee Kang-guk is said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying 777 airplane, and that flight was his first with the craft into San Francisco; plane's crew was not aware of danger until only seven seconds before crash.

byline.original: By NORIMITSU ONISHI, CHRISTOPHER DREW, MATTHEW L. WALD and SARAH MASLIN NIR
byline.contributor: Norimitsu Onishi reported from San Francisco, Christopher Drew and Sarah Maslin Nir from New York, and Matthew L. Wald from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Somini Sengupta from San Francisco; Michael Schwirtz, Ravi Somaiya, Jad Mouawad and Mei-Yu Liu from New York; David Barboza from Shanghai; and Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea. Jack Begg contributed research.

lead_paragraph: The pilot at the controls on Asiana Flight 214 was said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying a Boeing 777, and an airline spokeswoman said that it was his first time piloting a 777 into San Francisco.

headline.main: Terror on Jet: Seeing Water, Not Runway
headline.print_headline: Terror on Jet: Seeing Water, Not Runway
